node.text:
Welcome to the Pixel Precision tutorial on the Wiring tab!
We're going to go step by step to explain the basic of the Wiring tab and eventually get into some principles of sound, synthesizers and sound design.
This is an Output node. Each wiring MUST have one, it's what specifies what the final audio generated will be. Until it becomes relevant, it will be left empty in the tutorial.

The scrollable region this note is in is called the "Wiring Canvas".
Touch and drag and empty region to scroll.
Multitouch pinch to zoom. Multitouch drag to scroll with multiple fingers.

"Wiring" is a node-graph system and editor that specifies how you want the audio to sound when a keyboard key is pressed. Think of it like the virtual electronics or schematics of the noise generator.
Not only does this give you freedom to play around, you can see how any included instrument is authored!

The entire tutorial series will follow this format, where comments are littered in a wiring document. When visiting a new wiring, always make sure to zoom out first to take a notice of where all the content is; you don't want to miss anything.
As things get more advanced, there will be more functional and interactive demos. Feel free to edit and play around with the tutorial wiring. If you ruin something, you can just reload the original entire tutorial from the "Include Document" menu!
If you make changes you want to save, you will need to save it as a seperate document.
Click on the button "Goto Next Page" to continue this wild and manicly hedonistic pixie-dream fueled journey of post-it-note-trail-like education!

There's two ways of thinking about the form of editing that the Wiring system provides:
• There's a type of interface called a node-based interface, where you have "nodes" that can be connected to form "graph hierarchies".
• Not only is this a common form of editing, but audio manipulation also has a long legacy of doing this before computer editing was the norm in a physical form of audio manipulation called "patching". Where an audio cable with an audio signal would be plugged-in (a.k.a "patched") into another audio port, which would be plugged into another, then another, then an... , until finally being patched to the speaker to create physically audible noise.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(abstract_data_type)|The Wikipedia page on graph data structures.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Node_graph_architecture|The Wikipedia page on Node Graph Architectures.

Directly below are some extra links on the various subjects for anyone interested.
Reading and understand them is not necessary to this tutorial.

Did you zoom out and and take a look the layout and everything first?
We'll go over the different parts of the user interface.

First off, the individual nodes in the canvas can be touched and dragged to move them.
Try dragging this node by its titlebar.

If you're on this page for the first time, you may have gotten here by pressing the "Goto Next Page" button from page 1.
These buttons can do different things. There will usually be a comment next to them that describes what they do.
If you want to go to different pages, click on the wiring select up top. Click the button below to point it out.
These different pages are the tutorial are also wiring pages. These are where instruments will eventually be authored!

Wiring documents can be saved, and loaded from the hamburger button.
Press the button below to point it out.

On the bottom are test keys for quick access to keyboard keys when you're not in the Keyboard tab.
Press the button below to point it out.

On the left is the pallete of different nodes. They will be covered in more in depth in future pages.
Press the button below to point it out.
Also the sash (empty space) between the canvas and the pallete can be touch and dragged to redistribute the size.

On the bottom right is the E-Stop button. Also known as the emergency stop.
It is similar to the one in the Keyboard tab. This button can be pressed to instantly stop all playing audio.
You know the drill, press the button below to point it out.

The E-Stop button should be orange right now.
• When ORANGE, it has been detected that no sound will play when a key is pressed. • When WHITE, it has been detected that a sound "may" play when a key is pressed - but no sound is playing. • When RED, it means there is currently sound playing that will stop if the E-Stop is pressed.
That's all for the Wiring sections section

Some important regions of the Wiring editor were covered.
Next page we'll get more into the pallete and how to create nodes and point out the rest of the Wiring editor interface.

Nodes that are "encased", like this one, can't be moved.
A lot of tutorial comments will be encased, but nodes are hardly ever encased in practice.

In this page we're going to get more in depth on the palette.
The palette is the list of nodes on the very left of the Wiring tab.
If you need help identifying it, click on the button to the right. You may need to click on the sash and drag it out if it's too thin.

Click on nodes to see that node type highlighted in the Palette.
Some nodes have been provided below. Just tap on one of the nodes once to select them, and then tap on the selected node again. You should see an animation on the Palette, and the scrollbar will scroll if needed.
Tap (don't drag) the various nodes to view information about them. You can also tap the category names to view information about them to.

Try deleting the nodes directly below.
• Select a node, this will bring up the Delete region (if it wasn't visible before) • Then either... • Tap the delete button. • Drag the node by the title off the canvas into the delete region and drop it.
Select node, and either drag to delete canister, or press while selected to delete.

If you see a node in the canvas and you want to quickly find it in the Palette, simply double tap its titlebar to highlight it in the Palette.
The first tap selects the node. Any selected node that's tapped will highlight in the Palette.
This will not work for nodes that aren't listed, such as a the Output node.
Create a few nodes directly below this message. Don't worry about connecting them or doing anything fancy, just add them to the canvas for now.

That's all here! You're now a bonified pro at identifying the different areas of the Wiring editor.
Use the button below to advance to the next page where the basics on node connections will be covered.

To the top left of the Wiring canvas are the undo and redo buttons.
Keep in mind that changing the active Wiring will not log an undo or redo operation, but if the undo or redo being performed involved another wiring, it will be made the active one so you can see the change.

If you're been following along with the exercises and deleted the previous nodes, un-delete them with the Undo button.
If you need help finding the Undo button, click the button "Show Me!" to the right.

Now that you've done some undo operations, undo those undo operations with some redos. Test out pressing the Redo button.
If you need some help finding the Redo button, press the "Show Me!" button to the right.

It's time to get to the meat and potatoes with the Wiring tab.
That's right people, I'm talking about connecting nodes together and MAKING SOME NOISE!

Most nodes generate and transform audio, with the version connected to the "Output" node being what is played out.
Each wiring node must have one "Ouput" node. In the past pages, they had Output nodes but they were silent because nothing was connected to them. The Ouput of the current wiring (the one you see in the Wiring canvas) is the Output that key presses will be directed to.
There are triangles called "sockets" on the left and right of most nodes. • A socket on the left is an input. There may be multiple input sockets depends on the node type. • A socket on the right is an output. There will be at most one Output. Almost all nodes have Output sockets except for a few nodes in the "Special" category.

Let's give it a try. • Press the keys on the keyboard and note that nothing plays (and that the E-Stop color is orange). • "Sine" node's output to the "Output" node. • Try pressing keys on the keyboard again, audio should be heard.
For this exercise, only worry about connecting the Sine to the Output for now. Leave the ASDR node alone, we'll get to that in a bit.

To connect a node, tap and drag the output socket (right side) into another node's input socket (left side).
When dragging, you will see a line previewing the connection.
Note that "cyclic" networks cannot form. This means a node cannot connect to a node, which connects to another node, which con.... which eventually connects back to the first node.
When a node is selected, the output socket becomes larger. This can make is easier to drag.

When dragging, valid inputs are highlighted where the output can be dropped to.
When dragging on top of an input, a crosshair will be placed on the input. This can be used to determine if you're hovering over the input's hit zone one smaller touch screens where your fingers may visually occlude the input socket.

When reworking the wires of a Wiring, check the E-Stop to see if it's valid. If the E-Stop is white, it will probaby make a noise (if authored correctly). If the E-Stop is orange, the output does not pull in an audio stream from anywhere in its network.

When analyzing a Wiring network, check the wiring colors. "Orphaned" wires that don't eventually connect to the output will be white. All other wire connections that are used by the Output will have their wires colored the same as their nodes.

If you want to disconnect a wire connection, drag the wire from the output connection and drop it into empty space.
Give it a try, disconnect a wire.

After you've connected the Sine to the output, tested it with the keyboard and succeded, try adding the ADSR into the mix.
• Connect the Sine output socket to the ADSR input socket. • Connect the ADSR output socket to the Output.
To replace the wire into the Output, simply drag another one over it.
The Sine, ADSR and Output are not encased. Feel free to drag them around as needed. Don't worry about changing anything about the nodes or what the ADSR node does. But. if you connect them correctly, there should be a noticeable difference.

Dudes (and dudettes), this was a big moment, first steps! Manipulating nodes! Things only get more amazing from here.
The next page is going to cover some Special nodes that are going to be used quite often for the rest of the tutorial. Then we'll get into teaching some audio synthesis techniques you can use in this application.
There are two special nodes you'll be seeing often - they're used as tools to switch between different examples:

The QuickOut forwards an audio signal. What makes is useful is that is contains a button that can be pressed to instantly connect it to the Output.
This allows quickly and easily switching between different sections.

This page started with nothing connected to the output.
Test the keyboard, and then click the multiple "Connect Out" buttons on the right, testing the keyboard in between. Also notice how wiring connections are made to the Output.

With the sections of what the Wiring tab is and what its various parts are, what wirings are, all things nodes, and these commonly used utility nodes, we can FINALLY start really getting into the meat of talking about synthesizer concepts and how to make interesting sounds.
In the next section we're going to cover some basic primitives used for creating tones.

The Gate node provides a UI that allows switching between one audio signal or another.
This allows for A/B testing or for creating different modes. Think of it like an expression pedal of the fingers (or not, that's a weird way to put anything).
The Gate only affects the sound of any future notes played, not of any current playing.

Tap the QuickOut to the right to connect the Gate node provided to the Output.
It should start on input A. Press the keyboard to hear the Triangle Wave node it's connected to.
Then tap the "Gate" parameter (with the green or red switch in it) to switch to input B. The wire colors should change, and the color of the Gate parameter should be red and say "B". Pressing a key now should play the Sine wave from B.

The "Name" parameter isn't important, it's just a reminder of what the gate is for.
It can be edited but only 4 charaters are allowed. It's like the super-Twitter of labeling stuff.

A "tone" is a sound created from a repeating pattern - with the rate of which the pattern repeats is called the frequency. It's measured in "times per second", also called "hertz" or "hz" for short
Sound is much more than this repeating tones, It's a myriad of complex tones mixed together that come in and out at different ever-changing volumes.
But, we have to start somewhere...

We're going to talk a little about sound, and play with primitive tones.
Exciting times, people!

There are a common set of primitive tones and other audio generators used by audio applications including this one.
Each of these tones has is a type of audio that can be heard and has a unique quality - but should be though of like primary colors in a painting. They are combines in unique and interesting ways to create new types and qualities of sound.
We will go over the types of noise generators this application has.

There should be at least one noise generator in a wiring. There are 3 types of nodes in this application: • Noise generators • Noise modifiers (includes combiners) • Misc (i.e. Special)
The misc category isn't making any noise. And if there's no noise generated to pass into the modifiers, the modifiers aren't outputting any noise either. This means if there are no noise generators in a wiring that eventually makes its way to the output, there's a good chance the wiring's not making any noise.

The Sine wave is a tone created by plotting the trig sine function as audio data over time.
What exactly that means honestly isn't too important here. The more important thing is to listen to the sine wave and get familiar with it if you're not. Exercises to the right.
"Connect Out" the QuickOut to the right and play some keys to test what it sounds like.
Create a new Sine node by bringing it in from the Palette; and plug that one into the Output and test it.

Remember that the Output of the active wiring is what the keybord keys will play.
You're also viewing these tutorials by setting the active wiring to read its contents.
This means if you want to test the demos in this page on with more notes than just the test keyboard at the bottom the Wiring tab, you can always go to the Keyboard tab.

The triangle wave is called such because its wave shape looks like a bunch of triangles.
It has sharper sound to it than the Sine Wave.
"Connect Out" the QuickOut to the right and play some keys to test what it sounds like.
Create a new Triangle Wave node by bringing it in from the Palette; and plug that one into the Output and test it.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sine_wave|The Wikipedia article on Sine waves in general.
Also known as a sawtooth wave. It gets it name because it shape lookes like a saw.
"Connect Out" the QuickOut to the right and play some keys to test what it sounds like.
Create a new Saw node by bringing it in from the Palette; and plug that one into the Output and test it.
A wave that looks looks like a zipper made of boxes... I know, these descriptions are tough to describe without images. Check the Wikipedia links if you haven't! They contain purty pictures.
"Connect Out" the QuickOut to the right and play some keys to test what it sounds like.
Create a new Square Wave node by bringing it in from the Palette; and plug that one into the Ouput and test it.

Square waves can get LOUD!
Especially on smaller speakers where the Sine Wave and Triangle Wave didn't seem that loud, Square Waves can often be played more effectivly and be surprisingly louder, even if the audio data for their amplitudes are the same as the other wave types.

White Noise is just random data that "in theory" has every frequency at an even distribution. Note that this means White Noise will sound the same regardless of what keyboard key is pressed.
It's similar to listening to an old analog TV or radio with horrible reception.

"Connect Out" the QuickOut to the right and play some keys to test what it sounds like.
Play multiple keys, notice how they will all sound the same instead of changing in pitch.
Create a new White Noise node by bringing it in from the Palette; and plug that one into the Output and test it.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_noise|Open the Wikipedia page on white noise.

The Gate Wave is a Square Wave that goes from 0.0 to 1.0 instead of -1.0 to 1.0.
What exactly that mean's into too important - the key take away is that it's pretty much a Square Wave that will be half as loud. This is used for a style of audio manipulation effects called "gating", which is similar-but-not to the Gate node.
In a nutshell, you'll know if you need to use this instead of the Square Wave - for all other cases, just use the Square Wave for tone generation.
Try this one out or not. Knowing this one isn't too important for covering the basics. It's only here for completness.

This is used to insert in an unchanging value into input sockets.
A Constant Node by itself doesn't make noise because a constant value doesn't motivate the speaker to move.
But sometimes it's useful to put in a static value where an audio signal should be for certain effects.

Quite a lot of ground was covered. This was the entire "Wave" category - which is a misnomer because it's more than just wave types.
We will not make it a habit to cover entire categories for any future pages, but it was important for this category.
With every section that covers the basics and gets them out of the way, things are going to get more interesting and fun.
Now that some primitives have been covered, the next page will start cover how to combine them into new sounds.
Primitive noise generators are fine, but complexity comes from combining them together in interesting ways.

When modulating audio, be careful. Multiplying content of one frequency by another can create a tone that is a deceptivly higher pitch than its fundamental tone should be. While not a huge problem, it can cause problems with the "Identify Absolute Notes" exercise included in this application.
The explanation of fundamental tone will be covered later in the Overtones section.

Create your own similar setup
• Add in two new noise generator nodes from the Palette. • Combine them with either an add or subtract node. • Connect it to the output and test it.

Adding and subtracting audio waves will play one on top of another.
When adding, this generally means the audio will be louder. When subtracting, this generally means the audio will be quieter.
When overlapping audio, my policy is to add audio on top of each other unless I have a specific reason to subtract instead.

Play with the wiring to the right that takes in two different tones and either adds or subtracts them.
Toggle the gate ADoS and compare the different.
You'll notice they have a similar quality, but at different volume levels.

Phase cancellation is when two opposite waves are lined up exactly and cancel each other out.
This is the basic premise of how active noise canceling headphones work. A microphone will listen to the outside world and subtract a version of that from the audio playing through the headphones - which cancels outside audio that leaks through.
A simple demonstration of two exact waves canceling each other out can be tested to the right.
The Comb Mod node combines two audio signals by multiplying them together.

Audio signals are usually a bunch of streaming numbers that oscillate between a min and a max value - in this case -1.0 and 1.0.
This means if two waves line up, a double negative will result in a positive. This also means multiplying a tone generating node by another tone generating node of the same frequency will result in twice the frequency because the doubt negative will result in positives.

Test the setup to the right.
On the A gate is a Sine Wave On the B gate is a Sine Wave multiplied by itself.
Notice how the self modulated version sounds higher pitched and quieter. It has half the amplitude and double the frequency (one octave higher).

Crossfading is when an audio signal transitions from one to another.
This can be done with the Lerp Node. Lerp is short for "linear interpolation".
When its "Factor" input is 0.0, A is played. When its "Factor" input is 1.0, B is played. And value in between will be an interpolated transition value, with 0.5 being the average of the two audio signals. Any values below 0.0 or 1.0 will enhance the difference of one signal to another in an operation called extrapolation.

Test the setup to the right.
The Attack Node hasn't been covered yet (it will be covered in the Envelopes page). In a nutshell, the Constant Node and Attack node create an audio signal that starts at 0.0 and goes up to 1.0 over the timespan of 2 seconds.
This will result in a fade from the Sine Wave sound to the Square Wave sound.

Ways to combine audio together using nodes in the application were covered.
This was pretty much of section dedicated to the Combines category and the Min Node and Max Node were skipped, but they're pretty self explanatory.
In the next page we'll talk about attenuating and shaping the ends of a pressed keyboard tone to give it more character.

Depending on your speakers, or the speakers of your listeners, you may have notice poping sounds before and after the tones generated on past pages.
These are called transients. They're often created unintentionally, but they're a fact of life. It's when an audio signal has a quick change that causes the speaker to jerk in a way that causes it to make a poping sound.
There's a tool to help this issue called envelopes. Envelopes come in 4 stages...

Below is an example of a pure transient.
The demo below is silent except for a poping sound. That is the transient. This is done by waiting for half a second at -1.0, and then instantly sending an audio signal of 1.0.
If you have no modified your sample rate, the default is 44,000 samples a second. The common range of human hearing is 20hz to 20,000hz, with it usually being rare for adults to have good hearing above 17,000. If what you were hearing was the sound of the audio signal, it would be over twice the range of human hearing - and it would be imperceivably short.
What you're hearing instead is a side effect of demanding from the speakers what it cannot physically do.
Below is an example of a Sine wave without an envelopes. Depending on your speakers, you may hear a poping sound at the beginning and end. These are transients.
The first stage is called Attack. This is when a note is first pressed, the volume goes from 0.0 (silent) to 1.0, the loudest it will be.

Do the "Possible Transient" example on the right side.
Although up till now this has been pretty much every tone played, so you may have noticed poping earlier.

Do the "Definitive Transient" example on the right.
This should be audible on all speakers because it doesn't generate extra sound that the transient has to compete with to be heard.
The second stage is called Decay. The decay is the transition from the end of the attack (which again, is the loudest the instrument note will be) to a lower value called the sustain.

The Sustain is the the third stage. Once an instrument note is in sustain, it will remain in sustain until release.
For example: • if the instrument was a piano, releasing the note would be lifing the finger off the key. • if the instrument was a wind instrument, releasing note would be no longer blowing into it. • if the instrument was a guitar, this would be right after it was plucked.
Because Precision Keyboard is a virtual keyboard, release happens when you untouch a keyboard key.

After the instrument has been released, it will go into the Release stage.
An instrument may make lingering noise after it is release for a while before it becomes completly silent.

So these transients can be remedied by applying an attack at the beginning with a very short during, and a release at the end with a very short duration.
Note that even though I talk about the beginnig and end, this is refering to the audio signal, which ISN'T the same as the placement of the Attack and Release wiring node - which should be at the end of the audio signal it's processing.
And as mentioned before, these envelopes can help emulate the properties and stages of real instruments.

The Wiring system comes with separate Attack, Decay and Release nodes.
Sustain is achieved by setting the end volume of a Decay node.
If you heard a transient on the "Possible Transient" example, try the example below and examine the difference.
These are instances of them on the right.

Often audio programs will come with an envelope called an ADSR.
This is simply all 4 stages combined into one body of controls (or in this case, a single node).
That's where it gets its name, it's an acronym of all 4 stages in order. • Attack • Decay • Sustain • Release
Below in an ADSR. Play around with the parameters and play some notes to get familiar with it.

Now that you know the 4 stages of the ADSR and may find yourself using it for your wiring instruments, pay attention to the characteristics of the various instrument when you hear them in your favorite songs and on the radio.
Comming up on the next page, nodes that work by duplicate audio signals.
For unnecessarily complex reasons that I won't get into, using a Release or ADSR will add a few random fractions of a second to the sustain before entering the Release stage.
In this page, we're going to talk about the short, but ever-versatile list of nodes called the Voices category.

In a nutshell, voices take an audio stream and play it back multiple times.
Usually this is done with some kind of offset (if it just played it back exactly on top of itself, that would just be a multiplying factor, we've got the Amplify node for that).
This creates complex and "echo-y" qualities.
The Chorus node takes an audio signal and plays it back multiple times. Once for each "voice". With each voice, the frequency can have a slight pitch change applied and volume changed.

The Delay node takes an audio signal and plays it back multiple times with a time offset between voices, similar to the Chorus node. The main difference is that it cannot apply a pitch offset between voices.
While this may make it seem less capable, this means it is far more efficient since it can just buffer the audio signal to play the multiple voices.
A short delay can mimic reverb, while a long delay can mimic echos.

The ability to take audio file and repeat it gives up the tools to create interesting echos and warbling sounds that can help us emulate real-world effects as well as create odd and completly alien audio qualities to our instruments.
In the next section, we're going to quickly expand upon this to briefly talk about the workhorse of electronic music, the "super saw".

The Chorus node is computationally expensive to use. This is because in order to pitch shift an audio signal, it makes a duplicate for every voice which involves copying the node hierarchy. When using the Chorus node, try to move commutative operations to the right side of the node, outside of the the Chorus node's hierarchy.
So instead of something like this...
... The Amplify node is just a multiplication operation so it can be commuted to be connected AFTER the Chorus. This optimization sounds the same, but is computationally cheaper to synthesize.

The Chorus and Delay nodes in this app simply add the audio signals of the voices together. This can greatly increase the loudness. Be prepared to add an Amplify somewhere afterwards to lower the loudness level back to an acceptable leve.

Reverb is what happens when sound bounces around the room and gets multiple copies of the sound recorded with VERY minute time offsets (a.k.a. phase offsets).
Test the example below. Analyze the sound with and without the Delay.

Try the setup below. It's the same as the example above, except the offset time between voices has been increased greatly.
An Attack node has also been added to make it more obvious when a new voice is added.

Super saws is an umbrella category (i.e. genre) of sounds that are created by overlapping many sawtooth audio streams together.
It creates a type of sound that is prevelant through all types of electronic music, especially common in a type of instrument called a "synth pad".

To create the foundations of a super saw in the Wiring, plug a Saw Wave generator into a Chorus node and lower the offset to something REALLY low, not quite zero, but REALLY close. This create a phasey/flangey effect. Then turn up the "Voices" parameter to add more overlapping versions.
Typically you want this as high possible, which isn't always feasible because of how costly the Chorus node is in this application.

Experiment with the example below.
Especially with the various Chorus parameters. Since the Chorus' "Offset" parameter is so small, it's very sensitive to change, meaning you can nudge it a little and get a lot of variety.
Super saws can get complex with an insane amount of body and detail them. This is just a starting example.

Personally I think the vanilla version of the super saw sounds pretty good, but why not add extra nodes to experiment and try to find neat variations of it?
In the next section we'll be going over some of the nodes in the Operations category.
The biggest category of nodes are the Operations. They take in a single audio stream and transform it.

This page won't cover every single type of Operation node in the app.
Remember you can tap on them in the Node list for more information, you can play around with them, and also examine their usage in the Included Instruments.
Amplify and power amplify can raise or lower the volume level of an audio signal. The Power Amp node is the same as the Amplify node, but with different ranges of allowed multiplication.

The Square node multiplies each audio signal element by itself - as in it raises the audio signal to the second power. Keep in mind that this will half the amplitude, lower the DC and double the frequency of a tone.
The Cube node raises the audio signal to the third power. This is often used to give an audio signal more "body".
For these power nodes, it is best to have any tones before them set to a Gain of 1.0 and lower them with an Amplify node later.
Quantize, also known as posterizing or bit crushing. It turns an audio signals shape into a similar but "stair-stepped" version of it. The resulting sound is often described at "chip tuney".

In technical talk, the smear node does something similar to "blurring" the data by taking a weighted average of audio samples in a given region.
It tends to "round" out sharp audio signals and removed high frequency components. But, because audio is constant oscillating quickly, it often also makes audio quieter. It is suggest to use a Power Amp node afterwards to bring any quieted volume back up.
The MADdest Node Of Them All

The MAD (short for multiply-followed-by-and-add) operation node does just that; it takes an audio signal and multiplies it by a value, and then add a value on top of that result. This is a common enough compound operation that is has been given its own node.
One important use for it is to take an audio signal that tends to oscillate between [-1.0, 1.0] and remap it to [0.0, 1.0] so that it can be plugged into a Lerp's factor parameter.

The Operations category was covered, as well as a few nodes in the category. Beyond that, some techniques and concepts were shown using them.
On the next page we'll make a fun reference to a 90's boy band,.. enjoy.
"... designed a fly synth and I can't relax ..."

An LFO is short for low frequency oscillation.
What makes an audio signal audible that is that has changes that happen between a certain range of frequencies called the "range of human hearing". This is typically 20hz to up to 20,000hz. But, there can be changes in the audio signal that happen slower than 20hz that aren't audible but are noticable. These changes are called LFO.

A common LFO is "wobbling" the volume level. For example, think of the "wub wub" parts of a dub step drop. This can often be accomplished by limiting the amplitude of a tone with a low frequency wave.
The love child of interpolation and ping-ponging

Another type of LFO is a cross-fading LFO that uses the LERP. A lerp can "ping pong" back and fourth between two different audio signals at a noticeable rate. The frequency of the fading needs to be done slow enough, or else the pinging pattern will turn into a tone of its own.

Test the cross fading LFO below. There is a gate for the Lerping factor.
The top Sine wave going into the gate has a very low frequency of 1hz. Notice how the cross fading it very noticeable.
The bottom Sine wave going into the gate has a very high frequency of whatever the key note is. Note how the rate is so high that no cross fading can be detected, but instead sounds like a tone.

Remember there are different time parameters for a generator, including making a wave's frequency based off the BMP. This can also be used to make audio wobble to a beat - just make sure it's slow enough to be audible and not fast enough to sound like a tone.
Much of music is based on repitition, and I'm not talking about the lyrics of pop songs of today, but rather the physics and tonality of the sounds made.

Some concepts and tecniques involving the oscillating of audio data was covered.
The timbre of an instrument isn't just the repeating "shape" of an audio signal on the timescale of its frequency, but its repeating nature on larger timescale. The LFO is an example of that.

Musical notes are made from tones, which is a sound that can be played at a specific frequency. The "shape" of the wave isn't too important as long as it repeats at a certain frequency.
But, the shape does control the quality and character of the sound, also known as timbre. Timber in a nutshell is the difference between audio with the same frequency. For example, a Sine wave, Triangle wave and Square wave can be played at the same frequency even though they sound different.

Some node parameters have different frequency and time types.
In this app, frequency and time editors look the same because they're related to each other: • The frequency is how many times a repeating signal repeats a second. • A duration of a repeating signal will decide its frequency.
Even though they're directly related, some parameters are more useful to be described as a length of time, and others as frequencies.

Very often we'll want the frequency of a tone to be the note we're playing, but also often-enough we'll want something different or a variation of that instead.
The application comes with a few different types of frequency/duration types.

Time parameters can be set based off a multiple of note's frequency. When viewing the parameter in the Wiring canvas, it will have a small icon of a note with an X hovering above it.
If the parameter is tapped for editing, it will open an editor for the parameter that has a slider for the value, and a toggle group to set if the value is a multiplication factor or division factor.

Time parameters can be set based off the a multiple of note's frequency. Unlike the previous Frequency Multiple version, the value being edited is the power of 2 to use.
Each positive increment in the value's integer is the next power of 2. Each negative decrement in the value's integer is the new inverse power of 2. To know exactly what that means and how fractional values are handled - well, you should have paid more attention in Pre-Algebra class! (If you're not old enough to have taken Pre-Algebra yet, pay attention when you do!)

The value used is the power of 2 used to multiply the beat's frequency.
It's directly analogous to how the Note Octave works, except it uses the BPM to calculate the frequency.

Time parameters can be set based off a multiple of beat's frequency. When viewing the parameter in the Wiring canvas, it will have a small icon of a drum (primitive yes, but it's a tiny icon, gimme a break!) with an X hovering above it.
One wavelength (the length of time for a given frequency) of the beat is the BPS, or Beats Per Second. That is the BPM's (i.e. Beats Per Megalodon) frequency multiplied by 60.
If the parameter is tapped for editing, it will open an editor for the parameter that has a slider for the value, and a toggle group to set if the value is a multiplication factor or division factor.

Setting the time mode to Seconds will make it so the value of the parameter represents seconds of time.
The parameter icon in the wiring canvas has a small hovering clock.

Setting the time mode to Frequency will use the parameter's value as the frequency.
If the time parameter is not for frequencies but for a duration of time, it is instead reffered to as the wavelength - which is the length of time (in seconds) for a given frequency.
On the right is a Sine wave set to Note Muliplication mode. Notice the icon for its "Freq" parameter. Edit and test the difference.
On the right is a Sine wave set to Note Octave mode. Notice the icon for its "Freq" parameter. Edit and test the difference.

On the right is a Sine wave set to Beat Muliplication mode. Notice the icon for its "Freq" parameter. Edit and test the difference.
Also, the interface to modify the beat (i.e. BPM) is in the "Keyboard" tab.

There is an error in this page that was only spotted after it was written, and for technical reasons it cannot be directly corrected so instead I'm issuing this correction:
- BPM is actually short for Beats Per "Minute".
I'm sorry for this accident and will try my best to spot these issues before they become irreversable, in the future.

On the right is a Sine wave set to Beat Octave mode. Notice the icon for its "Freq" parameter. Edit and test the difference.
Also, the interface to modify the beat (i.e. BPM) is in the "Keyboard" tab.

On the right is a Sine wave set to Seconds mode. Notice the icon for its "Freq" parameter. Edit and test the difference.
Note that because a single second is 1hz and the lower bounds of human hearing is 20hz, if the time duration is too large then it will not produce an audible sound.
On the right is a Sine wave set to Frequency mode. Notice the icon for its "Freq" parameter. Edit and test the difference.
Try the example below. Notice the wobbling and how the timescale of it is vastly larger than the wavelength of an audio signal used to create a tone.

The two examples of LFOs here are just a tiny sample of LFO types.
Depending on the definition of LFO being used, any kind of synthesizer control that oscillates over lengths of time larger than the range of human hearing can be considered an LFO.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fade_(audio_engineering)#Cross-fading|The Wikipedia article on fading, specifically the bookmark on crossfading.
A big part of what defines a timbre of a tone are its overtones. Also known as upper partials.

The "fundamental" frequency is the frequency of the note to be played. The timbre of a note is also defined by its overtones. Overtones are extra frequencies added on top. These frequencies will be integeger multiples of the root frequency.
What to set the volume to of these extra frequencies are the secret sauce you need to figure out.

This is pretty much the end of the Wiring tutorial. Congratulations on making it to the end!
There are actually a couple more pages, but it's for supplimentary content that's not specific to the Wiring system.
For reference, let's start off with a simple Sine wave.

To the right is a simple overtone example. It's one overtone at twice the fundamental frequency.
Note how the volume of the upper partial (x2) is lower than the root note (x1). While not always the rule, usually the higher the upper partial, the lower its loudness will be.

To keep things simple we've limited the overtones count to 2 (with 3 wave generators total in the largest examples). But very often a very good and unique sound will have LOTs of overtones. Like,... dozens of them.
Adding together many multiple Sine waves, especially on tablets and cell phone devices, can be very computationally expensive. One trick that helps is to take into account that other wave types such as Square waves, Triangle waves and Sawtooth waves can be considered a composition of Sine waves with many specific upper partials added.

In this next example, a third overtone is added as a x3 multiple of the fundamental frequency.
Compare the difference between the this example and the previous example.
Also note how Add nodes are daisy chained together to add more than 2 signals together.

To the right is another example of having 2 overtones.
Note the frequency multiples are different and their loudness levels are different. Different (integer) multiples of overtones and their loudness levels will give different timbers.
Also notice how much lower their loudness levels are compared to the previous examples. This is because of how high their frequency scaling factor is. For higher frequencies, a little bit goes a long way. Make it too high and the tone might be overpowered by the higher frequency and the note will sound higher pitched in general instead of as timbre.
url|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ds0cmAV-Yek|A Smarter Every Day video talking about the Fourier Series.

To the right is a default Sine wave, we've seen this a million times, and now this makes a million and one.
Connect it and listen to it as a reference against the other Sine waves with overtones that are going to be added in the next few examples on this page.

To the right is an example as simple as it gets. Just one more overtone, and at the next integer increment (2).
Try it out and compare it to the previous baseline. Also play around with its Freq multiplication factor and Gain parameters and listen for differences.

A slightly more sophisticated example to the right.
Test it out, play around with it.

Same bat-song, different bat-verse.
To the right is another example very similar to the above with different contributions for the 3rd upper partial.
Test it out, play around with it, notice differences, write them down, call it science.

Audio sounds different depending on what's playing it.
Speaker made of different materials and different sizes reproduce audio frequencies differently. For example, a low powered and tiny cellphone speaker are typically terrible at playing sounds with low frequencies in them.
This is a physical constraint based on quality and physics. If you find yourself wanting better quality audio from this (or any other) application, consider getting the proper output - such as headphones, or a portable amplifier that can support playing low-frequency audio. This application isn't what I would call a "high-end" audio application, so be careful with powerful outputs, as transients and other audio issues and artefacts can cause problems.
Just don't use Bluetooth speakers. In my experience they don't handle audio well that intermittenly starts and stops - like what happens when keys are pressed and released.
There many things to take into consideration when designing notes and sounds. Some are specfiic to this application, many are not. Some are physical, some are computational.

Digital audio is made of many samples of audios streamed to speakers at incredibly fast and uniform intervals. These are called samples.
In the application, they are also sometimes referred to as "audio signal elements".
There is a balance that needs to be considered when specifying the sample rate. Use too many samples to synthesize a sound and it becomes more computationally expensive to generate. Use too few samples and audio quality becomes poor, and it also reduces the highest frequency that can be represented in the digital audio signal.
Very often it is set around 40,000 hz - because this is about twice the rate of the upper bounds of human hearing.

The computer is always under the clock to generate audio information exactly at the right time. As fast and precise as computers are, this still isn't feasible for the general processor (CPU).
Because of this, computers have dedicated audio hardware whose only responsibility is getting the audio samples turned into volage in speaker on time, every time. Because that is there only job, the CPU is still in charge of generating that audio information and the providing it to the audio hardware. In order for applications and this audio hardware to talk to each other, a "buffer" is shared, where the CPU will write audio data that the speaker should play (ahead of time) and the audio hardware will play that audio data when the time is right.
This buffer is small, because if it's too large, too much information will be generated about what audio needs to be played in the future, even if changes are made (such as a user lifting their finger off a keyboard key) - this delay from when an even happens to when it actually changed anything is called "latency". A larger buffer gives the CPU more time to do other stuff before it needs to come back to generate more new audio data, but at the cost of latency.
If the buffer is TOO small, it doesn't give the computer enough time to do other stuff before it needs to refill the audio buffers with new content. If the application doesn't refill that buffer in time, a "buffer underrun" occurs - and usually this can be detected by what I would describe as a "skipping" sound.
This is why computational complexity and cost of your synths is important. The application is always in a race to fill that buffer information, and the more time it needs to calculate that information, the greater the chance an buffer underrun will occur.

As previously mentioned, computational costs need to be considered.
Other solutions and compromises include: • Using better and more powerful hardware • Lowering quality settings • Adding switches to your synth to change the quality settings by additing or removing features in the sound • Optimizing the logic of any programable controls.

There is a limited range an audio signal is allowed to be. In this application the ideal range is set between [-1.0, 1.0].
Sometimes this limit is because of the range of the number type used to represent audio samples. But no matter what, there is a limit to the distance a speaker can move.
Clipping occurs when an audio signal uses values at a higher range that can be represented or played, at which point the maximum possible value is used. This distorts an audio signals shape to give it flat tops and bottoms, to make it more similar to square waves. This means no only is the audio's amplitude not being represented correctly, upper partials may be added from abruptly flatening an audio signal's shape.
Make sure the combined amplitude of the audio comming out of the speakers isn't so high that clipping occurs.
In this application, in the Keyboard tab there is a volume meter on the top right. Try to make sure this doesn't light up into the red section. If it does, lower the application's Master volume.

Temporal aliasing can happen when the frequency being generated is too high for the samples per second used to output the audio. In those cases odd "wagon-wheel" effects can happen where the frequency content can appear to get higher when playing a lower note, or sound lower when playing a higher note.
For any frequency of audio you want to capture in your instrument, it is recommended that it be less than half the samples per second rate used.

Technical issues that occur when processing data are called "artefacts".
Sometimes also spelt "artifacts", but I try not to use the second version or else it sounds like we're anthropologists and I'm simply too out-of-shape to outrun rolling boulders of death while wearing a sable fedora.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_(signal_processing)#Sampling_rate|The Wikipedia page on sampling, set to the bookmark on sampling rates.

All digital audio application work on the same premise of streaming sample values to the speaker.
In this application, this can be modified in Keyboard Tab > Data & Quality > Samples/Sec.

Back in the "before-times", computers had specific add-on called the "sound card" that was responsible for managing sound.
These days consumer machines have dedicated and integrated audio circutry their motherboards (and/or) CPUs that are good enough for a large majority of anybody's audio needs.

This is the final page with any actual substance in the tutorial.
The previous page was the last page with any interactive examples or information on wiring.
As a warning, this page is just going to have technical information. Attempts will be made to avoid present dense information and offloading excess content to outside links, but avoid dense technical information is not possible.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_underrun|The Wikipedia page on circular buffers - the type of buffer used for streaming media, including audio.
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulse-code_modulation|The Wikipedia article on pulse-code modulation, the method used to digitally represent audio information.
Some other things that make audio sound differently are: • The volume you're listening to it at. • The environment you're in. • Your distance of your ears from the speaker. • Other noises around you.

Not only do speakers have frequency responses, so do input devices like microphones, on how effectively they can capture audio of different frequencies.
Human hearing is no different. While the range of human hearing is between 20hz to 20,000hz and varies from person to person, within that audible range humans (as well as other hearing animals) are more-or-less sensitive to different frequency ranges.
One common model of this is called the "Fletcher-Munson Curves".
url|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equal-loudness_contour|The Wikipedia page on equal-loudness contours and the Fletch-Munson curves.

Understanding this section isn't necessary for playing around with the Wiring system. If it's all a bit too much, don't get discouraged - these are somewhat advanced concepts that can always be revisited later.
But the main take-away should be that there are real-world constaints that must be understood to fully utilize, navigate and troubleshoot any audio application - especially synthesizers or DAWs (digital audio workstation).
On the next page we'll conclude the tutorial. It will also have a button to play an applause to congratulate you for finishing the tutorial - but nothing to reach out and give you a pat on the back or shake your hand, the state-of-the-art for consumer electronics just isn't there, yet.

This is the end of the tutorial exploring the basics of the Wiring system.
Through this journey we have covered the UI of the editor in this application as well as covered some basic fundamentals of tone synthesis.
Some of the things covered are specific to this application, which other concepts are more general and can be translated sound design, other synths, and DAWs.
Congratulations on completing the tutorial! Now the fun can truly begin by weilding the basics to explore different permutations of nodes and their parameters, playing around with various ways to produce sounds, and exploring other included instruments.
To make it official, turn on your speakers and press the button below.
